titleStmt.title: Ursus, De nomine - Adbreviatio artis grammaticae (Codex Casanatensis 1086, folia 1r-11r)

publicationStmt.p: An experimental scholarly digital edition of section De nomine (folia 1r-11r) of the Adbreviatio artis grammaticae by Ursus from Benevento from codex Casanatensis 1086 (IX century), edited by Paolo Monella within the ALIM Project (2016).

sourceDesc.p: The source of this edition is constituted by the digital images of the manuscript provided by the Bibliotheca Casanatensis, Rome, Italy.

correction.p:
The following codes are used to categorize corrections identified in this edition:
ub
The scribe wrote 'b' for 'u', due to the pronunciation of the time.
mouilis
This could be considered a 'b'/'u' error, due to the pronunciation of the time. However, the scribe consistently wrote "mouil-" in the whole manuscript, which suggests that he was referring to the medieval etymological spelling of the adjective "mouilis, -e" (from verb "moueo, -es, moui, motum").
proprie_e_caudatum
Scribal error: "propriae" (with a final "e caudatum" grapheme) for adverb "proprie". This specific error occurs in 2v.a.27, 9r.a.18 and 10r.a.18.
dyp
The scribe consistently spells "dyphthongus" instead of "diphthongus". The confusion arises because "y" and "i" used to be have the same pronunciation at the time of the scribe.
iy
The scribe wrote "i" for "y", due to the pronunciation of the time.

The graphemes around "dicitur" are very hard to read. Another reading might be "oratio dici t(um) [two unclear graphemes] possunt uerba imperatiua et responsiua". In this case, the "u with r rotunda above" abbreviation should be expanded in "um", not "ur", which is unlikely. Also, the "p" and "o" of hypothetical "possunt" are very hardly recognizable. The reading that I am publishing ("oratio dicitur [...] sunt uerba imperatiua et responsiua") is more likely based on the manuscript.

ref.note: For section ab06 Morelli 1910, 291 mentions the following sources: "Donato K. IV. 372 25 sgg. e commentatori di Donato; Prisc. 54 segg." Donatus and Priscianus are imitated quite loosely in this section. I should inquire better about the commentaries on Donatus though. More specific imitations on Priscianus included in this section are referenced directly here. Possible comments on Donatus might include: (A) Seruius, K 4.405-K 4.448. For example K 5.81-K 5.312 and in particular on the parts of speech K 5.134 ff.

ref.w: aer Note that since here "ae" is no diphthong, it is written with two separate graphemes "a" and "e".

corr.note: Morelli 1910, p. 291, n. 3 corrects "inpura" to "in pure" and comments: "Cod. inpura. Correggo secondo la fonte di Ursus, Virg. gramm. p. 85,23 Huemer: "Pus in philosophia custodia dicitur, ut ait Origenes: Positis in pure fratribus solus evasit". The passage therefore discusses an etymology for word "corpus", composed ex an abbreviated ("corruptum") form of "corpus", namely "cor-", and the complete ("integrum") word "pus" (pus, -ris, neuter), which in this context means "custodia". Therefore "cor(dis) + pus (=custodia)" means "cordis custodia": the body is the custody, the shelter of the heart. To prove the meaning of "pus" as "custodia", Ursus cites Virgilius Grammaticus who, in his turn, cites Origenes. On this medieval meaning of "pus", see Jeudy, C. and Grondeux, A. (2002), 'À propos de "pus": sens médiéval d'un mot antique', Archivum Latinitatis Medii Aevi, 139-162, https://halshs.archives-ouvertes.fr/halshs-00008443. The text of Virgilius Grammaticus is readable online in https://archive.org/details/virgiliimaronisg00virguoft (J. Huemer, ed., Virgilii Maronis grammatici opera, Leipzig, 1886).
Scribal error: "aritmetrica" for "arithmetica".

ab.n: Another definition and etymology of nomen

ref.w: nomaOn the linguistic layer (LL), this word will not be able to be processed by a parser, as it does not exist in common dictionaries. Priscianus means this to be a previous (no longer existing) form of the word ὄνομα.

ref.note: This is an explanatory interlinear glossa. In the mansucript, it is linked to the main text by means of a cross sign between "nascitur" and "ut". The text in the glossa is closer to the source of this passage, i.e. Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.57.10-11: "principalis, ut 'Iulus', 'mons', deriuativa, ut 'Iulius', 'montanus'".

corr.note: The source of this passage is Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.58.26. Keil's apparatus says that Priscian's manuscripts BGKL have "quae... atoma" (neuter), while manuscripts P and H have "quas... atoma". Probably Ursus read a text of Priscian close to that of P and H. I agree with Keil, who corrects "atoma" of all manuscripts to "atomos" ("quas... atomos"). "Atomos" agrees with the previous "quas" because Latin substantive "atomus (or atomos), - i", like Greek "ἡ ἄτομος", is feminine (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

plius In his apparatus note to Priscianus, Ars grammatica, K 2.57.19, Keil mentions that Priscian's manuscripts GLK have "puplius", but corrects the name to its classical spelling "Publius". I, however, think that "Puplius" is the etymological spelling of the name that the scribe meant to write, so I am not correcting the "Puplius" spelling to classical "Publius" here or elsewhere in the text.

ref.note: One or more words of this sentence are illegible, so the specific syntax of the sentence is unclear.

Verg. Aen. 5.407 has "magnanimusque Anchisiades". Note the different spelling: Vergil has "Anchisiades", Ursus "Anchisades". Both spellings occur in the manuscript: "Anchisiades" is found twice, in 4r.b.20 (folio 4r, column b, line 20) and in 4v.a.2. "Anchisades" is found here and in 4v.a.1, so I woul not emend this reading in "Anchisiades".
"Pulcer" is an alternative spelling for "Pulcher", so I am not emending this word, but I am encoding "Pulcher" at the Linguistic Layer to facilitate the work of the lemmatizer.

The three final graphemes ("r", "u" and the "2"-like abbreviation mark above the "u") have been added above the line.
ref.note: The sense of the whole passage is obscure. I cannot find an emendation for the (very hardly legible) words "sine una eum idem". Also the punctuation sign after "idem" is very hardly recognizable, so the words "sine una eum idem" might or might not belong to the sentence "ea quam Donatus...". If, instead, "sine una eum idem" do not belong to that sentence, and the latter sentence starts with "ea quam Donatus", then "ea" might refer to the case in which a person only has one personal name. In this case, the whole sentence might mean that Donatus and most of the grammarians call this unique name a "cognomen", while Priscian calls it a "nomen". A possible translation might be: "That (scil. 'kind of proper noun') which Donatus and most (scil. grammarians) called 'cognomen', that is a denomination of a specific type, about which ('de qua', scil. 'de qua propriorum species') also Priscian said that the 'nomen' is specific of any single individual ('uniuscuiusque'); (this 'propriorum species', i.e. the name of a person who has only one name) cannot be a proper type of name ('non potest esse propria qualitas', lit. 'cannot be a specific/proper type of name')". This translation, however, does not make much sense anyway: if a person only has one name, how can this name not belong to the "propria qualitas"? I consider this passage a "locus desperatus".

ref.note: Morelli 1910, p. 292 writes that this passage has no source: "haec autem nomina ueniunt a futuris infiniti, mutata tum in men, ut prenotum ire prenomen, notum ire nomen, cognitum ire cognomen, agnitum ire agnomen".

Probably the same hand first wrote the abbreviation for "per", than changed his mind and added the bottom-left tail that made it an abbreviation for "pro".

ref.w: xxxiiii In the ensuing list in Ursus, I count no less than 40 types (42 if we include "primitiuae" and "deriuatiuae"). The source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.59.9, does not mention the number of the species, but simply writes: "Appellatiuorum multae sunt species".

ref.w: uerbialis The direct source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.60.4 has "uerbalia". The form "uerbialia" is in Pompeius, "Commentum Artis Donati", K 5.149.1. Lewis-Short has a lemma "uerbialis, e, adf.", but reports Pompeius as the only example. Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the adjective does never occur in classical Latin.

w.note: This allograph of the "÷" grapheme (logograph for "est") has a comma-like sign below the horizonta line and a regular dot above that line.

ref.note: For "acies ferri", see Plin., Naturalis Historia, 7.64.5: "acies ferri praestringitur" (from the same work, also see 7.63.3: "ea est caro informis, inanima, ferri ictum et aciem respuens"; 13.142.7: "sentire eum se capi durarique cornus modo et hebetare aciem ferri" 19.11.4: "ferri aciem vincunt"; 27.10.5: "quae cotibus in ferri acie deterenda"; 34.144.3: "nucleusque quidam ferri excoquitur in iis ad indurandam aciem"; 34.145.4: "neque alia genera ferri ex mera acie temperantur"; 34.154.1: "squama quoque ferri in usu est ex acie aut mucronibus".

Scribal error: "polionima" for "polyonyma".
The handwriting here is clear, but the syntax does now work with "quae" as nominative here.
I think that "Puplius" is the etymological spelling of the name that the scribe meant to write, so I am not correcting the "Puplius" spelling to classical "Publius" here or elsewhere in the text.

In the fourth position ("graDibus") two graphemes (a "u" and a "d") are overwritten one in the place of the other. Also in the sixth position ("gradiBus"), two graphemes (a "b" and a "d") are overwritten in the same way. A second hand corrected the original graphemes of the first hand in these positions. What is unclear from the manuscript is which graphemes were written by the first hand and which were written by the second hand. All manuscripts of the source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.60.12) have "Gradiuus Mars": I think that this was the text that Ursus could read. How did the error arise? One hypothesis is that the first hand wrote "grauidus" and the second corrected to "gradibus", which is in its turn a misspelling for "gradiuus" (with the very common scribal error "b for u", due to the scribe's pronunciation of "b"). A second hypothesis is that the first hand wrote "gradibus" and the second scribe did not understand that it was a misspelled form of "gradiuus" and mistakingly corrected it to the common adjective "grauidus". In either case, I would correct the form back to Priscian's "Gradiuus".

Strangely enough, "em" here is abbreviated with "e caudatum" and the "2" abbreviation sign. Also, while we tend to write "quemadmodum" as one word, and as such I am encoding it at the Lingustic Layer, the scribe spells it as two words, with a graphical space in between: "quem" "admodum". In consideration of the fact that the scribe often writes "ad" with no space after it, it might also be that the scribe is writing this expression as three separate words: "quem", "ad" and "modum".

corr.note: The implied subject of the relative clause should be feminine "ad quod (illa species) dicta est" and thus require "dicta est", as opposed to the manuscript's "dictum est". The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, 2.60.19) has: "Ad aliquid dictum est, QUOD sine intellectu illius, ad quod dictum est, proferri non potest". So in that case the subject is "quod" and the verb agreement is correctly "dictum est". The scribe probably changed "Ad aliquid dictum est" to "Ad aliquid dicta species est", but forgot to change the verb gender agreement accordingly.

corr.note: The source of this passage, Priscian, De figuris numerorum, K 3.413.24 has ἐπιμεριζόμενα. The text in this point of the manuscript is almost completely faded, especially the graphemes between "epi-" and "-omena". However, based on the number of graphemes that seem to be in this word, the scribe probably wrote a shorter word than ἐπιμεριζόμενα, apparently something like "eperizomena".

I expunged the word "inueniuntur" in this position. The original text of the manuscript was "inueniuntur infinitis tamen numerorum...". The source of this passage, Priscian "De figuris numerorum" (Keil 3.415.24-26), after "milies", has: "Infinitis tamen numerorum aduerbiis etiam n interponitur, quotiens totiens, similiter multotiens. Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes uel compositiones multae a nominibus numerorum, ut unicus...". Probably the scribe initially skipped the sentence "Infinitis... multotiens" (line 24 in Keil) and started copying from the sentence "Inueniuntur et aliae deriuationes" (line 26 in Keil), so he wrote "inueniuntur" (which originally had the initial "i" written with a larger size). Then, he decided not to skip the sentence "Infinitis tamen numerorum..." and copied it after "inueniuntur", but he forgot to erase "inueniuntur", which remained in the manuscript as a relic. The same scribe at a later time (or someone else) then erased the large initial "i" of "inueniuntur", overwrote it in rasura with a smaller size, and also overwrote the initial "i" of "infinitis" with a larger allograph. As usual, I kept the the original punctuation at the Graphemic Layer and put my propossed contemporary punctuation at the Linguistic Layer. The reason why no scribe decided to erase "inueniuntur" probably is that it could seem to belong to the previous sentence, which I do not believe.
The handwriting is not clear, but after the "n" there seem to be more than just an "a". If so, this is a scribal error ("septimania" for "septimana").

The text printed by Keil for the source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, Keil 2.65.18-2.65.20) mentions three different Greek nominative endings: "Si nominatiuus Graecus in 'ας' uel in 'ης' uel 'ιος' desinat, genetiuus uero in 'ου' diphthongum, a paenultima breuis ante 'des' inuenitur in patronymico". Ursus chose to mention one Greek nominative ending only ("ας"). However, different branches of the textual tradition of Priscian mention different Greek nominative endings, some of which (namely those of codd. R and L) might explain the error of codex Casanatensis for the genitive ("ος" for "ου"). Codex B ("cod. bibl. publ. Bambergensis"): "ac uel HC uel IOC". Codex b (same codex, second hand): "in ac uel ī HC uel ī IOC". Codex D ("cod. bibl. publ. Bernensis, olim Bongarsianus"): "in as uel in es uel in ios". Codex G ("cod. bibl. conventus Sangallensis"), first and second hand: "in as (with 'uel es' written above the line) uel ios". Codex K ("cod. bibl. Caroliruhensis 223"): "in ac uel IOC uel HC". Codex H ("cod. bibl. gymn. Halberstadiensis, Lutherius Krehlii"): "ac uel HC uel IOC". Codex R ("cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496"), first and second hand: "in as (with ac written above the word) uel in es (with EC written above the word) uel os (with IOC written above the word)". Codex L ("cod. bibl. publ. Lugd. Bat. olim Gruterianus"): "in as uel in os". As far as the ending for genitive is concerned, the erroneous reading "ος" (for "ου") appears in no manuscript of Priscian. The error in codex Casanatensis might have arisen from a misunderstanding of the text that we can read in codex R or, more likely, of the text that we read in codex L: the scribe might have mistaken Priscian's nominative ending "ος" in codex R or L for a genitive ending.

ref.w: peliades There is a macron over the "i", probably marking the quantity of the letter. A macron in the manuscript usually marks a long quantity, but in this case the quantity of both the "i" and the "a" should in fact be short. I am not encoding these quantity marks in the graphematic transcription because they do not have graphematic value, i.e. they do not create "minimal pairs" of words.

priamos There is an acute accent sign over the "i", marking the quantity of the vowel, or possibly simply the stress on that syllable. I am not recording such signs because they do not have graphemic value, i.e. they do not create "minimal pairs" of words.

corr.note: Scribal error: "priamoys" ("Πριάμους") for "priamoy" ("Πριάμου"). Compare the source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.66.39: "Πρίαμος Πριάμου". In line 4v.a.3 above the scribe wrote only two possible genitive endings for this category of nouns ("ος" and "ους"), while the source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.66.37-38) has three genitive endings: "ου", "ος" and "ους". Here, the scribe gave an erroneous ending Πριάμους (instead of the correct Πριάμου) to the genitive of Πρίαμος probably also because the correct ending "ου" was not listed among the possible genitive endings in line 4v.a.3.

"(Patronymicam speciem) eorum hominum": "a patronymic kind of nouns of men (regarding men) who (scil. had) an actual origin ('quibus ipsa derivatio') from the gods ('a dis')". See the next textual note for a possible translation of the whole emended sentence.

With my emendation, "patronyicam speciem" is the subject of the infinitive clause. This is my interpretation of this passage: "...because they (the 'gentiles') thought that there were many gods, and said that from their descent ('ex eorum genere', from the descent of the gods) there could be a patronymic kind of nouns ('dicebant... patronymicam speciem esse posse') of those men ('eorum iam hominum') who (scil. had) that origin ('quibus - scil. erat - ipsa derivatio') from the gods ('a dis')".

The source here is Priscianus, Ars grammatica K 2.71.11. Keil prints: "ᾔδην pro ᾔδειν". Kei'ls apparatus to the second word (ᾔδην) has: "11 ᾔδην scripsi, cf. Eustath. ad Hom. Od. XXIII 220 Sturzium de dial. Gr. p. 64 C.". and mentions the following readings in Priscian's manuscripts for this word: "ΗΔΗΝ H ΗΔ.ΙΝ Rr ΗΔΕ*Ν*(Ι) D ΗΔΕΝ K eden GL". The scribe undoubtedly wrote "edein pro eidein", a reading that comes from the manuscript(s) of Priscian that he could read. I am "correcting" the text only to make it match with what we know about the the ancient Greek and Ionian morphology. I remain unsure as to whether this correction is methodologically appropriate.
Note that the text written by the scribe is closer to that of codex R (and its second hand r) that to that of codex L. (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

The text written by the scribe is the same of codex R. It is different from that of codex L, which on other occasions was closer to Ursus' text. ei The source (Priscian Ars grammatica, K 2.74.17) has "ai" here, which would be more consistent with the following example of Greek Ἀχαιός. Keil's apparatus says that "ai" is the reading of r, d and h, while "ae" is the reading of R, D and H (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

add.w: u The first version of the text in the manuscript was "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus [sic] in 'i' longum interpositum pro consonante", where "interpositum" was probably meant to modify "i". A second hand added the word "u" above the line, thus changing the text into "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus in 'i' longum, interpositum 'u' pro consonante", where "solet conuerti ει dyphthongus in 'i' longum" is the main clause and "interpositum 'u' pro consonante" is an accusative absolute. I think that the latter (the text of the second hand) is the best one, so I am changing the punctuation at the Linguistic and Alphabetic Layers accordingly (I am adding a comma between "longum" and "interpositum" and other comma between "pro consonante" and "ut achiuus"). The source Priscian Ars grammatica, K 2.74.18 had an ablative absolute "interposita similiter u pro consonante".

w.note: This word is a very interesting use case for the encoding of abbreviations. The macron that crosses the long ascending trait of the "d" might well be interpreted as spanning not only over the "d", but also over the first grapheme. The latter, however, already is an abbreviation, since it is a "ŋ" brevigraph normally meaning "prae" (which, through monophthongation, becomes "pre"). So the first grapheme would be involved in two different abbreviations: it is a brevigraph per se, but it is also part of the abbreviation involving the whole word (marked by the macron above it). However, in my JavaScript code handling the XML/TEI code, I did not think of handling a case in which an "abbr" element is child of another "abbr" element. Also, the macron is mostly over the "d", so I am encoding this as though the macron was over the "d" only.

ref.w: isto The final "o" comes from the deletion of a previous "e".

ref.note: Who is "shown to be excellent" ("excellere ostenditur")? It might be "ipsos" (if "ostenditur" has an impersonal construction), referring back to the people ("personas", plural) mentioned shortly before. Or it might be "hic" (if "ostenditur" has a personal construction). It cannot be both. In favor of "ipsos" is the fact that the phrase "personas uel res" mentioned before is plural (like "ipsos"). Also in favor of "ipsos" might be the puctuation mark (followed by a larger initial) between "ostenditur" and "hic", however this mark should probably be ignored altogether, since "hic, cui 'ulterior' uel 'interior' adiungi uidentur" cannot be a separate main clause: if it were, subject "hic" would not be followed by any verb. In favor of "hic" is the very relative clause "cui 'ulterior' uel 'interior' adiungi uidentur" (where "cui" is singular, therefore must have a singular antecedent). I think that the case for "hic" is stronger. If "hic" is the subject of "excellere ostenditur", then "ipsos" might be meant as a direct object of "excellere", though in classical Latin the verb does not take an accusative as direct object. My interpretation would then be: "It is shown that a specific person ('hic'), to whom 'ulterior' or 'interior' seem to be attributed, surpasses them ('ipsos')". It should be noted that this sentence is not taken from the source (Priscian Ars grammatica, K 2.86.12-16), but is an addition by Ursus, so a non-classical syntactical construction might be possible.

corr.note: Possible constructions in classical Latin include "oportet comparatiuum vincere" (objective clause, like the one I am creating here by emending "comparatiuus" to "comparatiuum"), "oportet comparatiuus vincat" and "oportet ut comparatiuus vincat" (late Latin). Compare the examples in the Perseus Lewis-Short (A Latin Dictionary. Founded on Andrews' edition of Freund's Latin dictionary. Revised, enlarged, and in great part rewritten by. Charlton T. Lewis, Ph.D. and. Charles Short, LL.D. Oxford. Clarendon Press. 1879, retrieved from http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3Doportet on February 26, 2017): "With subj.: 'ex rerum cognitione efflorescat et redundet oportet oratio,' Cic. de Or. 1, 6, 20: 'me ipsum ames oportet, non mea,' id. Fin. 2, 26: 'valeat possessor oportet,' Hor. Ep. 1, 2, 49." Otherwise, it may be built with "ut and subjunctive" (late Latin).

ref.w:
ŋ pro
eliis
Interestingly, the scribe preferred using the brevigraph "ŋ" (for "pro") and then the grapheme for "e", thus preserving the diphthong, rather than reducing the diphthong "oe" to one "e" ("preliis") and using the abbreviation "p with horizontal trait" for "pre". This shows that the scribe was well aware that the classical Latin spelling included a diphthong in "proeliis".
ref.note: The source of this example is Cicero, Pro Rege Deiotaro 8, through Priscian, Ars grammatica K 2.93.18. Cicero's text (in Clark's 1918 edition) is: "istam, inquam, dexteram non tam in bellis neque in proeliis quam in promissis et fide firmiorem". Priscian's text (in Keil's edition) is the same, with an variant "dextera" / "dextra" in the manuscripts.

Lemma "prohibeo" in the Lewis-Short dictionary includes objective clauses such as "non posse" among the possible contructions of the verb: "with ut, ne, quominus, or an obj.-clause". The real problem lies in the double negative ("prohibeo" and "non"), that notoriously affirms. I am therefore expunging "non" to make the sense clearer. (Lewis-Short: A Latin Dictionary. Founded on Andrews' edition of Freund's Latin dictionary. Revised, enlarged, and in great part rewritten by. Charlton T. Lewis, Ph.D. and. Charles Short, LL.D. Oxford. Clarendon Press. 1879, retrieved from http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0059%3Aentry%3Dprohibeo on February 26, 2017).

es The source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.95.7 has: "assumunt genetiuo s et "simus" et faciunt superlatiuum". So probably the scribe had the alphabeme "s" in mind. He normally wrote the grapheme "s" in these cases, but here he wrote the name of the alphabeme as it was pronounced aloud (IPA /es/), instead of the corresponding grapheme. This is why, at the Linguistic Layer, I am simply enconding "s".

corr.note: If this is the direct object of "faciunt", it must be emended to "superlatiuum". The whole sentence might be influenced by a construction in the language spoken by the scribe similar to contemporary Italian "fanno al superlativo come 'locupletis'". If this is what the scribe had in mind, then "superlatiuo" would be a locative ablative. Also, the scribe may have been influenced by the previous dative "genitiuo".

Keil chooses the spelling "eculeus", of witness r, but reports that "equuleus" is the reading of manuscript L only, while witnesses Gg have "equleus" with a "u" added after "equ" in marginal position. This might provide evidence on what text of Priscian Ursus read.

ref.w: ar·ie·te Middle dots are used within this word to mark the metric scansion.
ref.note: The source of the example is Verg. Aen. 2.492: "labat ariete crebro", through Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.106.9 (with the same text).

The word "ariete" is repeated two times in this line ("ariete crebro pro ariete"). The difference in quantity of the syllables (that makes the difference between the two forms of "ariete") is marked through graphical marks: in the first "ariete", the allograph of the "r" is the one without ligature, followed by a middle dot. In the second "ariete", "r" and "i" are joined in a ligature.

corr.note: As the subject is singular "merces", I'd correct this to "facit". The scribe probably had in mind both "merces" and "apes" as logical subjects of this verb. However, the syntactical subject of this specific clause is "merces" alone.

ref.w: lenulus Plautus' text has "lenulle", but all Priscian's manuscripts have "lenulus" (in the discussion) and "lenule" or other forms with one "l" before the final "e" (in the Plautine quote, omitted by Ursus, which is Plautus, Poenulus 470-471: "Ita ut occepi dicere, / lenulle, de illa pugna"). Ursus' source is Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.109.6 (discussion) and K 2.109.11 (Plautine quote). Keil prints "lenullus" in both loci, but in the apparatus for K 2.109.6 he notes that Priscian's witnesses PBDHrglk have "lenulus", while in the apparatus for K 2.109.11 he writes "lenule DHKg lenulae K laenulae R laenule r" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum). Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the word "lenulus/lenullus" is a hapax in classical Latin, occurring only in the aforementioned Plautine passage. Perseus' Lewis-Short has lemma "lenullus" (http://www.perseus.tufts.edu), not "lenulus". I'll have to take this into account when I'll review the lemmatization.

corr.note: Scribal error: "us" for "nus", given the source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.109.12 "nus" and the sense of the whole passage. However, this discrepancy between the manuscipt and Priscian occurs in the same way for diminutives in "nus" (8r.a.37), in "na" (8r.b.11) and in "num" (8r.b.19), so it might be a deliberate choice by the scribe.

ref.w: uerbialia The direct source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.117.6 has "uerbalia". The form "uerbialia" is in Pompeius, "Commentum Artis Donati", K 5.149.1. Lewis-Short has a lemma "uerbialis, e, adf.", but reports Pompeius as the only example. Based on a search on the PHI 5.3 corpus with Diogenes 3.2.0, the adjective form "uerbialis" does never occur in classical Latin.

The source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K. .119.2-4 has: "inueniuntur tamen in uerbalibus etiam alias consonantes ante a habentia, sed quas a uerbis accipiunt, ut 'scribo scriba', 'conuiuo conuiua', 'colligo collega'".

Probable scribal error: "quodcumque" for "quotcumque". The witnesses of Priscian bear both readings. This is Keil's apparatus note: "quotcumque] rdh quodcumque RDH q***cunque K quocunque numero HL et in litura k". Note that in Priscian's manuscript RDH, the second hand corrected "quodcumque" to "quotcumque". This case (together with the "ος"/"ου" error in line 4r.b.31 and the carthina/chartina error in lines 10r.b.32-33, suggests that the text that Ursus read was close to the first hand of Priscian's codex R (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).

ref.note: This ":" grapheme has the function of a metamark inline, marking the point of the text in which the interlinear addition should be inserted. The ensuing "ł" (semicolon-like) grapheme is in interlinear position, with the function of a metamkark marking the beginning of the added text.

ref.w: habuit As the verb "habuit" is singular, its intended subject must be "ultima (scil. syllaba)": "eundem accentum (scil. subject 'uerba deriuatiua' from line 9v.b.27) seruant in ultimā (scil. syllabā), quem (scil. subj. 'ultima syllaba') prius habuit".

corr.note: This word is no direct object: it is governed by "esset".

corr.note: The source (Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.130.12) has: "a praesenti: 'saepio sapes', 'luo luēs', 'struo struēs', 'macero maciēs', 'luxurio luxuriēs', 'illuo illuuiēs'; a praeterito: 'rupi rupēs'". Priscian's codices G and K have "illues" instead of "illuuies" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum). I think that Ursus omitted the prefix "in-" ("il-") and made the common "b/u" error due to his contemporary pronunciation.

corr.note: I would emend "nominatiuus" to "nominatiui". There is no agreement between "nominatiuus" and "sunt" in this clause. The two possible emendations are "quorum nominatiui nunc in usu non sunt" or "quorum nominatiuus nunc in usu non est".

The sense requires the graphemes "ceritis" (alphabemes "ceritis", linguistic word "Caeritis" in classical Latin), as this is an example of a word with a short penultimate "i" (not "e"). Also see the source, Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.134.5-7: "inuenitur tamen et correptam i habens paenultimam apud eundem Uirgilium: Est ingens gelidum lucus prope Caerĭtis amnem".
Compare the source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.134.15: "custodio custos".
Scribal error: possibly the scribe meant to write "do dos dotis", so this word could be emendated to "dos". Compare the source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.134.16: "do dos".

There is a mark over each of the two "i"s of "aduentícíus". The same signs on the same position are on the words "commendatícíus" and "patrícíus". The shape of the signs sometimes looks like an acute accent mark, sometimes more like a macron. The second mark spans over both "i" and "u". The first sign marks the vowel's long quantity, but I am not sure about the meaning of the second mark, as the "i" should be short.

corr.note: This is possibly an error for "chartina", but if so, the error comes from Priscian's manuscripts. The source is Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.136.3. Keil prints "chartina chartinacius". In his apparatus, he writes "chartina] r carthina RD" and notes that a glossa to the "cod. Heidelb." explains: "epistola e charta quae a carpendo dicitur" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum). This error, together with the "ος"/"ου" error in line 4r.b.31 above and especially with the quodcumque/quotcumque variant reading in 8v.b.26, suggests that the text that Ursus read was close to the first hand of Priscian's codex R ("cod. bibl. imp. Paris. 7496").

As the previous word, this is possibly an error for "chartinacius", deriving from Priscian's manuscripts R and D. Keil (Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.136.3) prints "chartinacius" and in his apparatus writes: "carthinatius RA carthinacius r" (see http://www.unipa.it/paolo.monella/ursus/sigla.pdf for Keil's sigla codicum).
Scribal error: "perspico" for "perspicio". Compare the source Priscian, Ars grammatica, K 2.136.6-7: "perspicio perspicuus".

ref.w: declinantur The grammatical subject of the sentence is "forma", so this verb might be emended to "declinatur". However, it agrees "ex sensu" with an implied "uerba", so I am not emending it. The same situation is found in 11r.a.20: "Est (scil. forma) quantitatis, quae a magnitudine uel paruitate sunt dicta".

corr.note: Missing 'h' in transliteration from Greek.

w.note: The grammatical subject of the sentence is "quae (scil. forma quantitatis)", so the verb "sunt dicta" should be emended to "est dicta". However, it agrees "ex sensu" with an implied "uerba", so I am not emending it. The same situation had been found in 11r.a.10: "Est et appellatiuorum species tota Graeca, quae apud nos ex toto Graece declinantur".
